Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story:
I stood at the edge of the pool, my whistle hanging around my neck, sweat beading on my forehead. Today was the day of my family’s annual blessing ceremony, a tradition my father always led, but this year he asked me to take his place. My relatives gathered on the lawn, waiting for me to begin, their eyes full of expectation. I could hear my mother’s voice in my head, reminding me how important it was to honor our heritage, to show respect and leadership.

But as I glanced back at the pool, I saw a group of teenagers laughing, climbing onto the slippery edge, ignoring the bold red “No Diving” signs. My training as a lifeguard screamed at me to intervene, to enforce the rules and keep everyone safe. If I left the ceremony, I’d disappoint my family, maybe even embarrass them. If I ignored the pool, someone could get hurt, and I’d be failing in my duty as a lifeguard. My heart pounded as I stood frozen between the two worlds, feeling the weight of both sets of expectations pressing down on me, unsure which role I was supposed to honor first.
